sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x=2, correct to 4 decimal places.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. The derivative, f'(x), is:

f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

The Newton-Raphson formula is:

x_n+1 = x_n - f(x_n) / f'(x_n)

We'll start with an initial guess of x_0 = 2 and iterate until the result is accurate to 4 decimal places.

Iteration 1:
x_1 = x_0 - f(x_0) / f'(x_0)
x_1 = 2 - (2^3 - 2*2 - 5) / (3*(2^2) - 2)
x_1 = 2 - (8 - 4 - 5) / (12 - 2)
x_1 = 2 - (-1) / 10
x_1 = 2.1

Iteration 2:
x_2 = x_1 - f(x_1) / f'(x_1)
x_2 = 2.1 - (2.1^3 - 2*2.1 - 5) / (3*(2.1^2) - 2)
x_2 ≈ 2.0952

Iteration 3:
x_3 = x_2 - f(x_2) / f'(x_2)
x_3 = 2.0952 - (2.0952^3 - 2*2.0952 - 5) / (3*(2.0952^2) - 2)
x_3 ≈ 2.0951

Since the result has not changed after the third iteration to 4 decimal places, we can conclude that the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x=2 is approximately x ≈ 2.0951.
